instructions.description: Let's get started. Please ensure that the water basin and the milk basin are full and that the heating element is plugged in.  Once you are ready, press next step above.
Heat the milk to 86°F.
Add the starter culture by sprinkling it on top of the milk, and let it rehydrate for a few minutes before stirring it in with an up-and-down motion of the spoon.
Cover the milk and allow it to set, undisturbed, for one hour. If you are using coloring, stir it into the milk now.

Make sure that the milk is still at 86°F. Add the diluted rennet. Mix it in well, using gentle up-and-down motions. Stir it for 1 minute, then stir just in the top part of the milk for 2 more minutes.
Cover and let the milk set, undisturbed, for 1/2 hour.
If after 30 minutes you have a clean break, cut the curd into 3/8-inch cubes. Stir them gently, then press next.
Let the curds rest for 5 minutes.

Heat the curds and whey 2°F every 5 minutes, until they are at 102°F. Stir to prevent the curds from matting (sticking together). Maintain the temperature at 102°F for 1/2 hour. Periodically stir them gently during this time, trying to keep them from matting.

Heat the curds and whey 2°F every 5 minutes, until they are at 102°F. Stir to prevent the curds from matting (sticking together). Maintain the temperature at 102°F for 1/2 hour. Periodically stir them gently during this time, trying to keep them from matting.

Heat the curds and whey 2°F every 5 minutes, until they are at 102°F. Stir to prevent the curds from matting (sticking together). Maintain the temperature at 102°F for 1/2 hour. Periodically stir them gently during this time, trying to keep them from matting.

Heat the curds and whey 2°F every 5 minutes, until they are at 102°F. Stir to prevent the curds from matting (sticking together). Maintain the temperature at 102°F for 1/2 hour. Periodically stir them gently during this time, trying to keep them from matting.

Heat the curds and whey 2°F every 5 minutes, until they are at 102°F. Stir to prevent the curds from matting (sticking together). Maintain the temperature at 102°F for 1/2 hour. Periodically stir them gently during this time, trying to keep them from matting.

Heat the curds and whey 2°F every 5 minutes, until they are at 102°F. Stir to prevent the curds from matting (sticking together). Maintain the temperature at 102°F for 1/2 hour. Periodically stir them gently during this time, trying to keep them from matting.

Heat the curds and whey 2°F every 5 minutes, until they are at 102°F. Stir to prevent the curds from matting (sticking together). Maintain the temperature at 102°F for 1/2 hour. Periodically stir them gently during this time, trying to keep them from matting.

Heat the curds and whey 2°F every 5 minutes, until they are at 102°F. Stir to prevent the curds from matting (sticking together). Maintain the temperature at 102°F for 1/2 hour. Periodically stir them gently during this time, trying to keep them from matting.
Pour off the whey until the amount in the pot just covers the curds. Continuing to stir, add 60°F (cool) water until the temperature in the pot reaches 80°F.
Maintain the 80°F temperature for 15 minutes. Stir frequently.
Drain the curds in a colander lined with cheesecloth. Allow them to drain for 15 minutes. Pour the whey back into the basin.
Mill the curds, breaking them to thumbnail-size pieces and gently mixing in the salt.
Keep the curds in a colander at 98°F for 1 hour, flipping every 15 minutes.
Keep the curds in a colander at 98°F for 1 hour, flipping every 15 minutes.
Cut the curds into bite size pieces and enjoy!
Let's get started. Please ensure that the water basin and the milk basin are full and that the heating element is plugged in.  Once you are ready, press next step above.
Heat the milk to 86°F.
Add the starter culture by sprinkling it on top of the milk, and let it rehydrate for a few minutes before stirring it in with an up-and-down motion of the spoon.
Cover the milk and allow it to set, undisturbed, for 45 minutes. If you are using coloring, stir it into the milk now.
Make sure that the milk is still at 86°F. Add the diluted rennet. Mix it in well, using gentle up-and-down motions. Stir it for 1 minute.
Cover and let the milk set, undisturbed, for 45 minutes.
Cut the curd into 1/4 in cubes.
Let the curds rest for 5 minutes.

Heat the curds and whey 2°F every 5 minutes, until they are at 100°F. Stir to prevent the curds from matting (sticking together). Maintain the temperature at 100°F for 1/2 hour. Periodically stir them gently during this time, trying to keep them from matting.

Heat the curds and whey 2°F every 5 minutes, until they are at 100°F. Stir to prevent the curds from matting (sticking together). Maintain the temperature at 100°F for 1/2 hour. Periodically stir them gently during this time, trying to keep them from matting.

Heat the curds and whey 2°F every 5 minutes, until they are at 100°F. Stir to prevent the curds from matting (sticking together). Maintain the temperature at 100°F for 1/2 hour. Periodically stir them gently during this time, trying to keep them from matting.

Heat the curds and whey 2°F every 5 minutes, until they are at 100°F. Stir to prevent the curds from matting (sticking together). Maintain the temperature at 100°F for 1/2 hour. Periodically stir them gently during this time, trying to keep them from matting.

Heat the curds and whey 2°F every 5 minutes, until they are at 100°F. Stir to prevent the curds from matting (sticking together). Maintain the temperature at 100°F for 1/2 hour. Periodically stir them gently during this time, trying to keep them from matting.

Heat the curds and whey 2°F every 5 minutes, until they are at 100°F. Stir to prevent the curds from matting (sticking together). Maintain the temperature at 100°F for 1/2 hour. Periodically stir them gently during this time, trying to keep them from matting.

Heat the curds and whey 2°F every 5 minutes, until they are at 100°F. Stir to prevent the curds from matting (sticking together). Maintain the temperature at 100°F for 1/2 hour. Periodically stir them gently during this time, trying to keep them from matting.
Allow the curds to set for 20 minutes.
Drain the curds in a colander lined with cheesecloth. Place the colandar back into the pot and let sit for 15 minutes.
Remove the colander from the pot and place the mass of curd on a cutting board. Cut the curd into 3-inch slices. Put the pot into a sink full of 100°F water. Place the slices in the pot and cover.
Keep the curds in a colander at 100°F for 1 hour, flipping every 15 minutes.

The curd slices should be tough and have a texture similar to that of chicken meat. Break the slices into 1/2-inch cubes and put them into a covered pot. Put the pot back into the 100°F bath. Stir the curds with your fingers every 10 minutes for 30 minutes. Do not squeeze the curds, merely stir them to keep them from matting.
Remove the pot from the bath. Add the salt and stir gently.
Line a 2-lb cheese mold with cheese cloth. Place the curds in the mold. Press at 10 lbs of pressure for 15 minutes.
Press at 10 lbs of pressure for 15 minutes.
Remove the cheese from the mold and gently peel away the cheesecloth. Turn over the cheese, redress it.
Press at 40 lbs of pressure for 12 hours.
Remove the cheese from the mold and gently peel away the cheesecloth. Turn over the cheese, redress it.
Press at 50 lbs of pressure for 24 hours.
Remove the cheese from the mold. Peel away the cheesecloth. Air-dry the cheese at room temperature for 2-5 days, or until it is dry to the touch.
Wax the cheese.
Age it at 50 to 55°F for 3-12 months. This cheese develops sharper flavors as it ages.
Let's get started. Please ensure that the water basin and the milk basin are full and that the heating element is plugged in.  Once you are ready, press next step above.
Heat the milk to 91°F.
Hold milk at 91°F for 30 minutes.
Add the diluted calcium chloride and stir for 30 seconds.
Add the starter culture and stir until completely dissolved.
Cook for 30 minutes.
Crush rennet tablet, and disolve into a quarter cup of filtered water. Pour into milk and stir for 1 minute.
Crush rennet tablet, and disolve into a quarter cup of filtered water. Pour into milk and stir for 1 minute.
Cook for 1 hour.

Cut curds into cubes, using a curd cutter or a curd knife, no smaller than .5 cm and no larger than 1 cm.  Most cheese makers cut the curds in one direction, then cut them again 90° to the original cuts. Finally, they insert the knife at a 45° angle parallel to the original cuts to form uniform blocks. Cutting into equally sized pieces is important, it lets the whey drain from the curds evenly.
Increase temperature to 95°F.
Cook curds for 1 hour and 40 minutes, stirring gently every 10 minutes.
Line perforated pan with cheese cloth. Set into second pan to catch liquid. Using a slotted spoon, gently transfer curds to perforated pan to drain. Leave the whey in the SousVide Supreme.
Fold cheesecloth over drained curds to cover them and place pan over whey. They whey should not touch the pan; ladle out whey if needed.
Cook for 10 minutes
Cut matted curds in half widthwise. Flip half of the loaf onto the other half. Cover with cheesecloth and replace lid.
Cook for 15 minutes.
Cut matted curds in thirds lengthwise. Flip the loaf over. Cover with cheesecloth and replace lid.
Cook for 15 minutes.
Cut each loaf in half lengthwise. Flip three loaves on top of the other three.
Cook for 15 minutes.
Rotate loaves so the outer surfaces are now on the inside.
Cook for 15 minutes.
Flip loaves so tops are now on bottom.
Cook for 15 minutes.

Cut loaves into curds, weigh, and place in covered container. Add salt, 1% by weight of finished curds, and shake vigorously. All of the salt should be absorbed into the curds. The curds will retain their squeak for about one day.
